question: One of the co-directors of a documentary about Central Asian media landscapes is best known for establishing what radical transparency organisation in the mid-2000s?
llm_answer: The provided context does not mention any co-director of a documentary about Central Asian media landscapes or the establishment of a radical transparency organization in the mid-2000s.

context.text: I pitied and loved him. And when I saw the movie right after Mastroianni died, I thought that Fellini and Marcello had taken a moment of discovery and made it immortal. There may be no such thing as the sweet life. But it is necessary to find that out for yourself. Preferences Favorites In an essay looking back at his first 25 years as a film critic, Ebert wrote: If I had to make a generalization, I would say that many of my favorite movies are about Good People ... Casablanca is about people who do the right thing. The Third Man is about people who do the right thing and can never speak to one another as a result ... Not all good movies are about Good People. I also like movies about bad people who have a sense of humor. Orson Welles , who does not play either of the good people in The Third Man , has such a winning way, such witty dialogue, that for a scene or two we almost forgive him his crimes. Henry Hill, the hero of Goodfellas , is not a good fella, but he has the ability to be honest with us about why he enjoyed being bad. He is not a hypocrite. Of the other movies I love, some are simply about the joy of physical movement. When Gene Kelly splashes through Singin' in the Rain , when Judy Garland follows the yellow brick road, when Fred Astaire dances on the ceiling, when John Wayne puts the reins in his teeth and gallops across the mountain meadow, there is a purity and joy that cannot be resisted. In Equinox Flower , a Japanese film by the old master Yasujirō Ozu , there is this sequence of shots: A room with a red teapot in the foreground. Another view of the room. The mother folding clothes. A shot down a corridor with a mother crossing it at an angle, and then a daughter crossing at the back. A reverse shot in the hallway as the arriving father is greeted by the mother and daughter. A shot as the father leaves the frame, then the mother, then the daughter. A shot as the mother and father enter the room, as in the background the daughter picks up the red pot and leaves the frame. This sequence of timed movement and cutting is as perfect as any music ever written, any dance, any poem. Ebert credits film historian Donald Richie and the Hawaii International Film Festival for introducing him to Asian cinema through Richie's invitation to join him on the jury of the festival in 1983, which quickly became a favorite of his and would frequently attend along with Richie, lending their support to validate the festival's status as a "festival of record". He lamented the decline of campus film societies: "There was once a time when young people made it their business to catch up on the best works by the best directors, but the death of film societies and repertory theaters put an end to

status as a "festival of record". He lamented the decline of campus film societies: "There was once a time when young people made it their business to catch up on the best works by the best directors, but the death of film societies and repertory theaters put an end to that, and for today's younger filmgoers, these are not well-known names: Buñuel , Fellini , Bergman , Ford , Kurosawa , Ray , Renoir , Lean , Bresson , Wilder , Welles . Most people still know who Hitchcock was, I guess." Ebert argued for the aesthetic values of black-and-white photography and against colorization, writing: Black-and-white movies present the deliberate absence of color. This makes them less realistic than color films (for the real world is in color). They are more dreamlike, more pure, composed of shapes and forms and movements and light and shadow. Color films can simply be illuminated. Black-and-white films have to be lighted ... Black and white is a legitimate and beautiful artistic choice in motion pictures, creating feelings and effects that cannot be obtained any other way. He wrote: "Black-and-white (or, more accurately, silver-and-white) creates a mysterious dream state, a simpler world of form and gesture. Most people do not agree with me. They like color and think a black-and-white film is missing something. Try this. If you have wedding photographs of your parents and grandparents, chances are your parents are in color and your grandparents are in black and white. Put the two photographs side by side and consider them honestly. Your grandparents look timeless. Your parents look goofy. The next time you buy film for your camera, buy a roll of black-and-white. Go outside at dusk, when the daylight is diffused. Stand on the side of the house away from the sunset. Shoot some natural-light closeups of a friend. Have the pictures printed big, at least 5 x 7. Ask yourself if this friend, who has always looked ordinary in every color photograph you've ever taken, does not suddenly, in black and white, somehow take on an aura of mystery. The same thing happens in the movies." Ebert championed animation, particularly the films of Hayao Miyazaki and Isao Takahata . In his review of Miyazaki's Princess Mononoke , he wrote: "I go to the movies for many reasons. Here is one of them. I want to see wondrous sights not available in the real world, in stories where myth and dreams are set free to play. Animation opens that possibility, because it is freed from gravity and the chains of the possible. Realistic films show the physical world; animation shows its essence. Animated films are not copies of 'real movies,' are not shadows of reality, but create a new existence in their own right." He concluded his review of Ratatouille by writing: "Every

Daniel Myrick (born September 3, 1963) is an American film director, most famous for horror films , especially for co-directing and writing the 1999 psychological horror The Blair Witch Project with Eduardo Sánchez . They won the Independent Spirit John Cassavetes Award for this film. Early life Myrick was born in Sarasota, Florida . He graduated from University of Central Florida School of Film in 1994. Career Along with collaborating with future Blair Witch cohorts Eduardo Sánchez and Gregg Hale on a trilogy of short films, Myrick supported himself by working as an editor and cinematographer on a number of Florida-based music videos and commercials. After he wrote and directed the promo for the Florida Film Festival in 1997, Myrick's work caught the eye of independent film guru John Pierson , helping to set the stage for the eventual 1999 debut of Myrick and Sanchez's first feature as co-writers and directors. In 2006, he co-founded Raw Feed , a direct to DVD division of Warner Home Video that specialized in horror films, with The X-Files executive producer John Shiban and 24 executive producer Tony Krantz . In 2025, Myrick endorsed a bill in the Maryland General Assembly to exonerate people convicted of witchcraft in Colonial Maryland , stating that "We are a flawed nation, and were born out of doing some incredibly cruel things” and that a belated "symbolic" recognition of past injustice was better than none at all. Filmography Feature films The Blair Witch Project (1999) Solstice (2007) Believers (2007) The Objective (2008) Skyman (2019) Television films Under the Bed (2017) Short films Curse of the Blair Witch (1999) Sticks and Stones: Investigating the Blair Witch (1999) Black Veil (2021) Web series The Strand (2006) Television episodes Split Screen (1997-2000) (unknown episodes) References External links Wikiquote has quotations related to Daniel Myrick . Daniel Myrick at IMDb v t e

a record-breaking $2.16 million (the previous record being $1.5 million), to assist paying his tax liens and other debts. Cage purchased the comic in 1997 for $110,000. The comic had been stolen from him in 2000, and Cage had received an insurance payment on the item. In March 2011, it was found in a storage locker in the San Fernando Valley and was verified by ComicConnect.com to be the copy sold to Cage previously. Worth around $25 million by May 2017, Cage was reportedly "taking [film] roles left and right" in order to pay off his remaining debts. By 2022, Cage confirmed that he had finally paid off his debts and intended to be more selective with his film roles. Legal issues Kathleen Turner wrote in her 2008 memoir, Send Your Roses , that Cage had stolen a chihuahua and was arrested twice for driving drunk while they filmed Peggy Sue Got Married . Later she admitted Cage did not steal a chihuahua and she was sorry. Cage won a libel action against Turner, her publisher Headline Publishing Group , and Associated Newspapers (whose publication the Daily Mail had repeated the allegations when they published an excerpt from the book). Christina Fulton sued Cage in December 2009 for $13 million and for the house in which she was living. The suit was in response to an order that she leave the dwelling; the order resulted from Cage's financial difficulties. The case was settled in June 2011. Cage was arrested in New Orleans' French Quarter district on April 15, 2011, for suspicion of domestic abuse battery , disturbing the peace and public intoxication. A police officer was flagged down by onlookers after Cage allegedly grabbed his wife's upper arm while appearing to be under the influence of alcohol. Cage was held in police custody until a bail of $11,000 was posted by Duane "Dog" Chapman . He was later ordered to appear in court on May 31, 2011. The New Orleans District Attorney announced that the charges against Cage had been dropped on May 5, 2011. See also Film portal Coppola family tree List of oldest and youngest Academy Award winners and nominees References External links Wikimedia Commons has media related to Nicolas Cage . Wikiquote has quotations related to Nicolas Cage . Nicolas Cage at the American Film Institute Catalog Nicolas Cage at IMDb Nicolas Cage at the TCM Movie Database

This movie could be found on YouTube in Canada when it first released in 2006. It is nowhere to be found on YouTube now, in Canada. Also information on Rob Mcgann is very limited. American Zeitgeist is a 2006 documentary film by Rob McGann. It discusses the war on terror and religion. It was the winner of the best feature-length documentary award at the Houston International Film Festival . Cast Tariq Ali Paul Berman Richard Bulliet Noam Chomsky Steve Coll Hamid Dabashi David Frum Christopher Hitchens Samantha Power Craig Unger References External links Review of American Zeitgeist in Opendemocracy.com American Zeitgeist at IMDb v t e

in 2006, leaving him severely disfigured and unable to speak or eat normally. However, his ability to write remained unimpaired and he continued to publish frequently online and in print until his death in 2013. His RogerEbert.com website, launched in 2002, remains online as an archive of his published writings. Richard Corliss wrote, "Roger leaves a legacy of indefatigable connoisseurship in movies, literature, politics and, to quote the title of his 2011 autobiography, Life Itself ." In 2014, Life Itself was adapted as a documentary of the same title , released to positive reviews. Early life and education Roger Joseph Ebert was born on June 18, 1942, in Urbana, Illinois , the only child of Annabel ( née Stumm ), a bookkeeper, and Walter Harry Ebert, an electrician. He was raised Catholic , attending St. Mary's elementary school and serving as an altar boy in Urbana. His paternal grandparents were German immigrants and his maternal ancestry was Irish and Dutch. His first movie memory was of his parents taking him to see the Marx Brothers in A Day at the Races (1937). He wrote that Adventures of Huckleberry Finn was "the first real book I ever read, and still the best". He began his writing career with his own newspaper, The Washington Street News , printed in his basement. He wrote letters of comment to the science-fiction fanzines of the era and founded his own, Stymie . At age 15, he was a sportswriter for The News-Gazette covering Urbana High School sports. He attended Urbana High School, where in his senior year he was class president and co-editor of his high school newspaper , The Echo . In 1958, he won the Illinois High School Association state speech championship in "radio speaking," an event that simulates radio newscasts. "I learned to be a movie critic by reading Mad magazine ... Mad 's parodies made me aware of the machine inside the skin – of the way a movie might look original on the outside, while inside it was just recycling the same old dumb formulas. I did not read the magazine, I plundered it for clues to the universe. Pauline Kael lost it at the movies ; I lost it at Mad magazine" — Roger Ebert, Mad About the Movies (1998 parody collection) Ebert began taking classes at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign as an early-entrance student, completing his high school courses while also taking his first university class. After graduating from Urbana High School in 1960, he attended the University of Illinois and received his undergraduate degree in journalism in 1964. While there, Ebert worked as a reporter for The Daily Illini and served as its editor during his senior year while continuing to work for the News-Gazette . His

Furama Hotel, the construction of the new tower AIA Central commenced in November 2002. AIA Central is a 37-storey grade A office building with a gross floor area of approximately 41,777 square metres. It provides 26 floors of prime office space, each of some 13,000 – 15,000 square foot lettable area with a total gross area of 450,000 square foot. The building was developed by Bayshore Development Group Limited, a joint venture of AIA and Lai Sun Development Company Limited. want him to do it another way on the next take, he can adapt to that too. Nicholson won his second Oscar, an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor , for his role of retired astronaut Garrett Breedlove in Terms of Endearment (1983), directed by James L. Brooks . It starred Shirley MacLaine and Debra Winger . McGilligan claims it was one of Nicholson's most complex and unforgettable characters. He and MacLaine played many of their scenes in different ways, constantly testing and making adjustments. Their scenes together gave the film its "buoyant edge", states McGilligan, and describes Nicholson's acting as "Jack floating like a butterfly". Nicholson continued to work prolifically in the 1980s, starring in such films as: The Postman Always Rings Twice (1981); Reds (1981), where Nicholson portrays the writer Eugene O'Neill with a quiet intensity; Prizzi's Honor (1985); Heartburn (1986); The Witches of Eastwick (1987); Broadcast News (1987); and Ironweed (1987). Three Oscar nominations also followed ( Reds , Prizzi's Honor , and Ironweed ). John Huston , who directed Prizzi's Honor , said of Nicholson's acting, "He just illuminates the book. He impressed me in one scene after another; the movie is composed largely of first takes with him." In the 1989 Batman movie, Nicholson played the psychotic villain, the Joker . The film was an international smash hit, and a lucrative deal earned him a percentage of the box office gross estimated at $60 million to $90 million. Nicholson said that he was "particularly proud" of his performance as the Joker: "I considered it a piece of pop art ", he said. 1990–1999: Established actor Nicholson (right) and Dennis Hopper at the 62nd Academy Awards , 1990 For his role as hot-headed Col. Nathan R. Jessup in A Few Good Men (1992), a movie about a murder in a U.S. Marine Corps unit, Nicholson received yet another Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor. One review describes his performance as "spellbinding", adding that he portrayed "the essence of the quintessential military mindset". Critic David Thomson notes that Nicholson's character "blazed and roared". The film's director, Rob Reiner , recalls how Nicholson's level of acting experience affected the other actors during rehearsals: "I had the luck of having Jack Nicholson there. He knows what he's doing, and he comes to play, every time out, full-out performance! And what it says to a lot of the other actors is, 'Oooooh, I better get on my game here because this guy's coming to play! So I can't hold back; I've got to come up to him.' He sets the tone." In 1996, Nicholson collaborated once more with Batman

Lee Young-Sun ( Korean : 이영선 ; RR : I Yeong-seon , born 21 February 1974) is a retired female javelin thrower from South Korea . Her personal best throw is 58.87 metres, achieved at the 2002 Asian Games in Busan . International competitions * New model javelin References Evans, Hilary; Gjerde, Arild; Heijmans, Jeroen; Mallon, Bill ; et al. "Lee Young-sun" . Olympics at Sports-Reference.com . Morning Joe is an American morning news talk show, which airs weekdays from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. Eastern Time on the cable news channel MS NOW . It features former US Representative ( Independent ) Joe Scarborough reporting and discussing the news of the day in a panel format with co-hosts Mika Brzezinski (whom Scarborough married in November 2018), Willie Geist , who regularly co-hosts from Tuesdays to Fridays, and Jonathan Lemire , along with recurring and special guests. History Morning Joe began as a fill-in program after Don Imus ' Imus in the Morning was canceled in April 2007. Former Florida Republican Congressman Joe Scarborough, then host of the primetime MSNBC program Scarborough Country , suggested the idea of doing a morning show instead. He put together what would become Morning Joe with Scarborough Country executive producer Chris Licht and screenwriter John Ridley . The pun in the show's title is echoed by a coffee ring in its logo. On April 16, 2007 (Imus' show aired until April 11, 2007 on MSNBC), the show debuted as one of a series of rotating programs auditioning for Imus's former slot, with Scarborough joined by co-hosts Mika Brzezinski and Ridley. Scarborough had personally asked Brzezinski to co-host with him the night before the first audition, while she was a "cut-in" presenter during MSNBC's primetime schedule on a freelance basis. Ridley quickly dropped out as main co-host but continued as a regular guest, while Willie Geist was tapped as co-host. The program permanently took over the slot in July 2007, though the decision was not officially announced until October that year. During the first quarter of 2009, Morning Joe earned higher ratings in the age 25-54 demo category than CNN 's competing program, American Morning , but had fewer viewers overall. Both programs finished behind Fox News 's Fox & Friends during the same time period. By March 2010, the show's ratings remained behind those of Fox & Friends , but surpassed its other cable competitors American Morning , Morning Express with Robin Meade , and Squawk Box . Morning Joe continued to regularly place second in total viewers and younger demographic to Fox & Friends , ahead of other cable news competitors including CNN 's New Day . However, Morning Joe ranked behind CNN's counterpart programming during short stints in 2013. Over the years, the program's focus has shifted partly toward enterprise journalism : Scarborough and Brzezinski provide exclusives from the United States Congress , the US State Department , and the White House .  On May 4, 2017, an MSNBC spokesperson confirmed that Scarborough and Brzezinski were engaged to be married. Their style in running the show was then parodied by Saturday Night Live with Kate McKinnon and Alex Moffat . In May 2017, for the first time in

communities.summary:
**Title**: American Zeitgeist Documentary

**Summary**:  
"American Zeitgeist" is a 2006 documentary by Rob McGann that explores the intersection of religion and the war on terror. The film features prominent thinkers such as Noam Chomsky, Christopher Hitchens, and Tariq Ali, and it won the best feature-length documentary award at the Houston International Film Festival. Once available on YouTube in Canada, the film is now difficult to find online, and information about its director remains scarce.

**Keywords**:  
American Zeitgeist, Rob McGann, war on terror, religion, documentary

**Title**: Daniel Myrick Horror Career

**Summary**: Daniel Myrick, born in 1963 in Sarasota, Florida, is best known for co-writing and co-directing the 1999 psychological horror film *The Blair Witch Project* with Eduardo Sánchez, which earned them the Independent Spirit John Cassavetes Award. After graduating from the University of Central Florida School of Film in 1994, Myrick worked on short films, music videos, and commercials before gaining recognition through a 1997 Florida Film Festival promo. He later co-founded Raw Feed, a Warner Home Video horror label, and in 2025 publicly supported a Maryland bill to exonerate colonial-era witchcraft convictions. His filmography includes *Solstice*, *Believers*, *The Objective*, and *Skyman*.

**Keywords**: Blair Witch Project, horror director, Raw Feed, witchcraft exoneration, independent film

**Title**: Rosie O'Donnell's Controversial Commentary

**Summary**: Rosie O'Donnell generated repeated media firestorms during her 2006-2007 tenure on *The View* through outspoken critiques of the Catholic Church, the Iraq War, and Donald Trump, as well as racially insensitive remarks. Her comments—ranging from calling radical Christianity “as threatening as radical Islam” to questioning the 9/11 collapse mechanics—provoked fierce backlash from conservative commentators and on-air clashes with co-host Elisabeth Hasselbeck. These highly publicized disputes, especially the split-screen confrontation over whether U.S. troops were being labeled “terrorists,” culminated in O'Donnell’s early exit from the show, though the controversy simultaneously delivered record ratings for ABC.

**Keywords**: Rosie O'Donnell, The View, Iraq War criticism, Catholic Church controversy, Elisabeth Hasselbeck feud

**Title**: Joe Scarborough Political Feuds & Career

**Summary**:  
Joe Scarborough, former Republican congressman turned MSNBC host, has been a central figure in high-profile political conflicts, most notably with Donald Trump, who revived debunked conspiracy theories about Scarborough’s involvement in a former aide’s death. Scarborough’s political career was marked by staunch conservatism, including anti-abortion stances and support for budget cuts, though he also took moderate positions on environmental and human rights issues. After resigning from Congress in 2001, he transitioned into media, creating and co-hosting *Morning Joe*, which became a major platform for political discourse and a frequent target of Trump’s attacks.

**Keywords**:  
Joe Scarborough, Donald Trump feud, Morning Joe, political controversy, media career

**Title**: Call Me by Your Name Acclaim

**Summary**:  
"Call Me by Your Name" garnered widespread critical praise, topping numerous 2017 best-film lists and securing major awards, including the Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay and the GLAAD Media Award for Outstanding Film. Timothée Chalamet’s performance earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor, making him one of the youngest nominees in history. The film also sparked debate over its portrayal of an age-gap relationship, with some critics questioning the power dynamics between the characters. Despite this, it developed a devoted global fanbase, inspiring pilgrimages to filming locations in Italy and fueling ongoing discussions about a potential sequel.

**Keywords**:  
Academy Awards, age-gap controversy, critical acclaim, fanbase, sequel plans

**Title**: Peter Guber’s Entertainment Empire  

**Summary**:  
Peter Guber parlayed a 1968 Columbia Pictures traineeship into a five-decade career that spans film, television, music, sports, and digital media. After climbing Columbia’s executive ranks, he became an independent producer of hits like *Rain Man* and *Batman*, then co-led Sony Pictures to industry-record box-office share and Oscar nominations. Through Mandalay Entertainment he built a multimedia conglomerate whose divisions finance, produce, and distribute theatrical features, Netflix films, and high-rated TV movies, while Mandalay Sports Media created ESPN’s most-watched documentary, *The Last Dance*. Simultaneously, Guber co-owns the NBA’s Golden State Warriors, turning them into a championship franchise and one of the league’s most valuable properties.  

**Keywords**:  
film production, Mandalay Entertainment, Sony Pictures, Golden State Warriors, The Last Dance

**Title:** Jack Nicholson’s Acting Legacy  

**Summary:**  
Jack Nicholson’s career is marked by a series of iconic, psychologically complex roles that showcase his intelligence and improvisational skill, from the unhinged Jack Torrance in *The Shining* to the anti-authoritarian Randle McMurphy in *One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest*. Directors like Kubrick, Forman, and Antonioni praised his ability to embody literate, edgy characters while bringing spontaneity and depth to every performance. Despite frequent Oscar recognition, Nicholson remains modest about his method-acting roots, emphasizing instinct and adaptability over technique. His collaborations with legendary actors and directors, along with memorable turns in films like *Chinatown*, *Terms of Endearment*, and *Batman*, cement his status as one of cinema’s most magnetic and versatile stars.  

**Keywords:**  
Jack Nicholson, method acting, iconic roles, improvisation, Oscar winner

**Title**: John Cena’s Entrance Theme

**Summary**:  
“The Time Is Now” is John Cena’s best-known entrance theme, used in WWE from 2005 through his 2025 retirement match. Recorded with his cousin Marc “Trademarc” Predka and producer Jake One, the track samples M.O.P.’s “Ante Up,” prompting a short-lived 2008 lawsuit that was later dropped. Released as the lead single from Cena’s debut album *You Can’t See Me*, the song also became an Internet meme and anchors Cena’s rapper-turned-superstar persona that evolved from early-2000s freestyle segments on *SmackDown*.

**Keywords**:  
John Cena, WWE entrance theme, The Time Is Now, You Can’t See Me, Ante Up sampling

**Title:** Roger Ebert’s Critical Philosophy  

**Summary:**  
Roger Ebert viewed film as an art form whose merit lies in execution, not subject matter, insisting “it’s not what a movie is about, it’s how it’s about what it’s about.” He championed animation, documentaries, and black-and-white photography for their power to reveal emotional essence beyond literal reality. Personal favorites—*Citizen Kane*, *La Dolce Vita*, *The Third Man*—reflected his admiration for morally complex, humanistic storytelling. Even after cancer left him unable to speak, he continued writing passionate, star-rated reviews that balanced intellect with emotional honesty until his death in 2013.  

**Keywords:**  
film criticism, animation advocacy, black-and-white aesthetics, emotional honesty, Life Itself

**Title**: Lee Young-Sun Javelin Career

**Summary**: Lee Young-Sun is a retired South Korean female javelin thrower born in 1974. She achieved her personal best of 58.87 m at the 2002 Asian Games in Busan. Her career is documented across several international sports databases including Olympics at Sports-Reference.com, World Athletics, Olympedia, and InterSportStats.

**Keywords**: javelin thrower, South Korea, 2002 Asian Games, personal best, retired athlete

**Title**: New Hampshire Lakes Region

**Summary**:  
The Lakes Region of east-central New Hampshire is anchored by Lake Winnipesaukee and dotted with dozens of smaller lakes, spanning Belknap County and parts of four adjacent counties. Beyond its famed waterfronts, the area adds low mountain scenery via the Belknap and Ossipee ranges and draws summer crowds to events like Motorcycle Week and races at New Hampshire Motor Speedway. Tourism fuels the economy, with attractions ranging from the family arcade Funspot and Gunstock ski area to the historic resort town of Wolfeboro and the Castle in the Clouds estate. The region’s picturesque settings have also served as filming locations for movies such as *On Golden Pond* and *What About Bob?*

**Keywords**: Lake Winnipesaukee, tourism, Belknap County, Motorcycle Week, On Golden Pond

**Title**: Raymond Carver's Literary Legacy

**Summary**: Raymond Carver, a seminal figure in late-20th-century American short fiction, is renowned for minimalist, “dirty-realist” portrayals of working-class despair. His tightly edited collections—shaped first by Gordon Lish’s drastic cuts and later by his own push for authorial control—include *What We Talk About When We Talk About Love*, *Cathedral*, and the posthumously restored *Beginners*. Carver’s poetics of brevity, blue-collar empathy, and precise detail spawned numerous scholarly studies, a prestigious Syracuse University reading series, and a wide array of film/theatre adaptations from Altman’s *Short Cuts* to Iñárritu’s Oscar-winning *Birdman*.

**Keywords**: Raymond Carver, minimalism, short stories, Gordon Lish, adaptations

**Title**: Richard Pleasance Music Career

**Summary**: Richard Pleasance is an Australian multi-instrumentalist, songwriter, and producer best known as a founding member of Boom Crash Opera, co-writing hits like “Great Wall” and “Onion Skin” and co-producing their double-platinum album *These Here Are Crazy Times*. After leaving the band in 1992, he launched a solo career with the ARIA-nominated album *Galleon*, toured with Elvis Costello, and formed the duo Felt. Pleasance has since composed iconic TV themes for *SeaChange* and *Wentworth*, produced records for artists such as Deborah Conway, Suzanne Vega, and Archie Roach, and continues to release solo material from his Hepburn Springs studio.

**Keywords**: Boom Crash Opera, Galleon, SeaChange, ARIA Awards, producer

**Title**: Graham Norton's Media Career

**Summary**:  
Graham Norton is a prominent Irish-British broadcaster best known for hosting *The Graham Norton Show* and serving as the UK’s Eurovision Song Contest commentator since 2009. He co-hosted the 2023 Eurovision final and has been involved in various Eurovision-related events, including talent shows and anniversary specials. Beyond Eurovision, Norton has had a prolific career in radio, television, film, literature, and advocacy. He hosted a weekend show on BBC Radio 2 for a decade before moving to Virgin Radio UK, and later stepped back to reclaim his weekends. Norton has also acted in films, released memoirs and novels, and voiced characters in major animated features like *Soul*. His personal life includes public relationships, a 2022 marriage, and past controversies, notably involving comments on cancel culture and transgender rights.

**Keywords**:  
Graham Norton, Eurovision, BBC Radio 2, The Graham Norton Show, British television

**Title**: AIA Central Skyscraper  

**Summary**:  
AIA Central is a 37-storey, 185 m Grade-A office tower in Hong Kong’s Central district, completed in 2005 on the former site of the Furama Kempinski Hotel. Developed by Lai Sun, CapitaLand and AIG and designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill to evoke a Chinese junk, it became AIA Group’s headquarters and was renamed from AIG Tower in 2009. The project overcame financial turmoil after the 1997 Asian crisis, with AIG and Singapore’s Pidemco acquiring a 65 % stake in the hotel site in 2000, leading to demolition in 2001 and construction start in 2002.  

**Keywords**: AIA Central, AIG Tower, Hong Kong skyscraper, Central district, Skidmore Owings & Merrill

**Title**: Morning Joe Controversies & Feuds

**Summary**:  
Morning Joe has repeatedly found itself at the center of media firestorms, from its 2009–2013 Starbucks sponsorship that drew mockery from Jon Stewart to on-air gaffes like Joe Scarborough’s F-bomb and Mark Halperin’s slur against President Obama. High-profile clashes include Scarborough’s on-air spats with Rush Limbaugh over Republican loyalty, a viral 2013 interview in which Russell Brand scolded the hosts for unprofessional banter, and a 2017 Twitter war with Donald Trump that escalated into allegations of National Enquirer blackmail. Recurring themes are accusations of superficiality, lapses in journalistic decorum, and the show’s shifting relationship with political power.

**Keywords**:  
Morning Joe controversies, Starbucks sponsorship, Jon Stewart feud, Trump Twitter war, on-air gaffes

**Title:** Carver’s Love & Violence Stories  

**Summary:**  
These chunks revolve around Raymond Carver’s 1981 collection *What We Talk About When We Talk About Love*, summarizing its bleak, spare tales where affection collapses into abuse, neglect, or murder. Characters—married couples, old friends, strangers—grapple with failed communication, emotional numbness, and sudden eruptions of violence (fatal beatings, hit-and-runs, suicide). The excerpts also trace the book’s editorial history: Gordon Lish heavily cut the stories, Carver later restored originals in *Beginners*, and multiple tales were adapted into film, TV, and song, cementing Carver’s influence on minimalist fiction and popular culture.  

**Keywords:**  
Carver, minimalist fiction, love & violence, Lish editing, Beginners

**Title**: AIA Group Asia-Pacific Profile

**Summary**:  
AIA Group Limited, headquartered in Hong Kong, is the largest publicly traded pan-Asian life insurer, operating in 18 Asia-Pacific markets through wholly owned subsidiaries and joint ventures. Spun off from AIG in 2010, it raised HK$159 billion in its Hong Kong IPO and has since tripled in market value while managing US$221 billion in assets. Beyond core life, health and accident insurance, AIA provides retirement planning, wealth management and variable contracts, reinforced by exclusive bancassurance partnerships with Citibank since 2013. The group has expanded via major acquisitions such as ING Malaysia and bolsters brand visibility through multi-year shirt sponsorships of Tottenham Hotspur and the Singapore Premier League. In 2024 Hong Kong’s Insurance Authority fined AIA HK$23 million for anti-money-laundering control deficiencies between 2016-2022.

**Keywords**: AIA Group, Asia-Pacific insurance, Hong Kong IPO, Citibank bancassurance, AML fine

**Title**: Raymond Carver’s Final Stories

**Summary**:  
These chunks center on Raymond Carver’s 1988 collection *Elephant and Other Stories*, the last seven stories he completed before his death.  The pieces repeatedly return to themes of financial strain, family obligation, and emotional exhaustion: narrators are bled dry by relatives’ demands for money, haunted by failed marriages, and left wrestling with guilt, resentment, and fleeting hope.  Several plots—*Elephant*, *Intimacy*, *Menudo*, *Whoever Was Using This Bed*—feature middle-aged men caught between duty and self-preservation, while the historical vignette *Errand* closes the book with Chekhov’s dignified acceptance of mortality.  Throughout, Carver’s spare prose exposes the fragile bargains people make to keep going.

**Keywords**:  
family debt, marital collapse, Raymond Carver, *Elephant* stories, emotional fatigue

**Title**: AIA Group Corporate Profile

**Summary**: AIA Insurance Holdings Limited (HKEX: 1299) is a pan-Asian life-insurance leader that began as American Asiatic Underwriters in Shanghai in 1918 and later became the Hong Kong-listed spin-off of AIG. After a failed US$35.5 billion takeover by Prudential, AIA went public in October 2010 with a US$20.5 billion IPO—then the world’s third-largest—followed by major acquisitions in Sri Lanka (Aviva NDB) and Malaysia (ING units). Today it serves over 3 million Hong Kong policyholders (about one in four medically insured residents) and has held the #1 MDRT membership ranking across Hong Kong and Macau for 17 straight years, although its weighting in the Hang Seng Index has since fallen to 4.72%.

**Keywords**: AIA, Hong Kong IPO, life insurance, MDRT, Hang Seng Index

**Title:** Morning Joe Show Evolution  

**Summary:**  
Morning Joe is MSNBC’s weekday morning talk show (6–10 a.m. ET) created by Joe Scarborough after Don Imus’s 2007 cancellation. Starting as a rotating audition program, it secured the slot in July 2007 and gradually out-rated CNN’s morning offerings while consistently trailing Fox & Friends. The show expanded to a fourth hour in 2022 and spun off radio, weekend-recap, and pre-dawn editions (Way Too Early, Morning Joe First Look). Its hallmark is a revolving panel of high-profile journalists, ex-politicos, and analysts—e.g., Mika Brzezinski, Willie Geist, Jen Psaki, Chris Matthews, Peggy Noonan—who dissect politics, policy, and culture from 30 Rock.  

**Keywords:** MSNBC, Joe Scarborough, Mika Brzezinski, political talk show, Morning Joe spinoffs

**Title**: Lochmere Archaeological District Heritage  

**Summary**:  
The Lochmere Archaeological District in Belknap County, New Hampshire, preserves a continuous record of human activity from Middle Archaic through Late Woodland periods, later serving as the historic homeland of the Winnipesaukee Pennacook. Its strategic Winnipesaukee River location fostered early Euro-American industry starting in the 1770s, but downstream mill owners gained water rights and shuttered local mills by 1882. Ninety acres encompassing 13 prehistoric and 18 historic sites were listed on the National Register in 1982, though modern development and river-channel work have partially impacted sensitive areas.  

**Keywords**: Lochmere Archaeological District, Winnipesaukee River, Pennacook, prehistoric sites, industrial heritage

**Title**: Nicolas Cage Career & Legacy

**Summary**:  
Nicolas Cage, born Nicolas Kim Coppola, is an Oscar-winning American actor and producer whose eclectic, genre-spanning career has earned him both blockbuster success and cult-icon status. After changing his name to avoid nepotism, he rose from early roles in *Fast Times at Ridgemont High* and *Valley Girl* to critical acclaim in *Moonstruck* and an Academy Award for *Leaving Las Vegas*. Known for intense, unpredictable performances—termed “mega-acting”—Cage has starred in action hits (*The Rock*, *National Treasure*), indie gems (*Mandy*, *Pig*), and voice roles (*Spider-Verse*, *The Croods*). Beyond acting, he owns Saturn Films, has directed *Sonny*, and was inducted into the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 1998.

**Keywords**:  
Oscar winner, versatile actor, cult icon, Coppola family, mega-acting
